prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom, even though the wife suggested the basement. Because of his job with a lot of conference calls, the wife has to manage the kids and household tasks without disturbing him, which limits her ability to do her own work and chores. She told him that if he stays in the bedroom, she can't guarantee silence, but if he moved to the basement, they'd leave him alone. He's upset she isn't quiet, and she's upset he didn't move.

First, I need to figure out who's at fault here. The key points are the setup of the office location and the resulting disruptions. The husband chose the bedroom over the basement, which the wife suggested. The basement would have been a better location for him to work undisturbed, allowing her to manage the house more freely. But he picked the bedroom for a better view. Now, the wife is dealing with the consequences of his choice, which affects her ability to work and handle chores.

The wife's argument is that he should have chosen the basement to avoid the conflict. She can't control the kids or household noises if they have to stay in the bedroom. The husband's argument is that she's not keeping it quiet. But the root issue is his decision to work where it's harder to keep quiet. He has the option to move, but he refuses, leading to her being restricted in her own home.

The user is the wife, asking if she's wrong. The options are A (she's wrong) or B (she's not wrong). Since the husband made the choice that causes the problem, and the wife is reacting to his decision, it's more likely that the husband is the one at fault. The wife is not at fault for trying to manage her responsibilities under his chosen setup. So the answer should be B.
